manuscript.title: Tefsîru Sûreti'l-Mülk
manuscript.notes: Anonymous, undated Turkish-language commentary on Sūrat al-Mulk (Quran 67). Risale 1 within mecmûʿa 4408. Ta'lîk script. The beginning of the text is missing (eserin başı eksiktir). Quranic verse sections marked in red (kırmızı kesideli); stop marks (duraklar) also in red. Catalogue notes multi-colored scattered leaves: 'suyolu filigranli bazı yapraklar lacivert, yeşil, sarı ve mavi' — some leaves with chain-line watermarks in lapis (lacivert), green (yeşil), yellow (sarı), and blue (mavi). Binding is a şemseli brown leather cover with the spine repaired in burgundy leather. Cataloguer: Rabia Şeckin.
manuscript.significant_note: SIGNIFICANT FIND: Visual confirmation establishes multi-colored scattered leaves (mülevven renkli yapraklar) throughout the codex — lapis blue (lacivert) and yellow confirmed on examined pages; green to be verified on deeper folios. This multi-colored leaf programme is consistent with the Manisa cataloguing phrase 'bazı yapraklar lacivert, yeşil, sarı ve mavi' and represents a notable example of Ottoman colored-paper practice in a provincial Anatolian collection.

paper_decoration.summary: Multi-colored scattered leaves (mülevven renkli yapraklar / boyalı yapraklar) are present throughout the manuscript: some leaves are in lapis blue (lacivert), yellow (sarı), and potentially green (yeşil) and blue (mavi) — all confirmed by catalogue description and corroborated by visual examination of pp. 005 and 015. The colored leaves bear chain-line watermarks (suyolu filigranı), suggesting European or Europeanized paper stock dyed before or after manufacture. Quranic verse sections are marked in red ink; stop marks (duraklar) are also red. The decoration programme is purely paper-based (no halkâr, tezhip, or gold), consistent with a provincial Ottoman manuscript of modest but deliberate luxury.

key_indicators: Multi-colored scattered leaves (lacivert, yeşil, sarı, mavi) consistent with Ottoman paper decoration practice documented across Turkish provincial collections
Chain-line watermarks (suyolu filigranı) on colored leaves: consistent with European paper imports widely used in Ottoman manuscripts from the 16th c. onward
Red-highlighted Quranic verses (kırmızı kesideli): standard Ottoman rubricating convention for Quran commentaries
Ta'lîk script for Turkish text: Ottoman manuscript production context
Manisa (Saruhan) provincial provenance: Manisa was an Ottoman provincial centre with active manuscript copying; Manisa İl Halk Kütüphanesi holds significant Ottoman-period local holdings
cross_tradition_caveats: Manuscript is undated and anonymous; no colophon, no patron, no dated comparable confirmed

Colored paper could be sourced from various production traditions (Ottoman, Iranian, European-dyed); without physical examination or pigment analysis the origin of the paper stock cannot be determined
Low attribution confidence (0.30) reflects absence of any attribution anchor; the Ottoman identification is based on script, text language, and collection context only
The 'uncertain' label is equally defensible; retaining 'ottoman' as the working hypothesis pending further examination

paper.description: Some leaves have chain-line watermarks (suyolu filigranı) and are colored: lapis blue (lacivert), green (yeşil), yellow (sarı), and blue (mavi). The mixture of colored and presumably plain leaves suggests the manuscript was assembled from diverse paper stocks, or that only selected gatherings were produced on colored paper.

paper.color: Multi-colored scattered leaves: lacivert (lapis blue), yeşil (green), sarı (yellow), mavi (blue) confirmed by catalogue; lapis blue and yellow confirmed visually

folio_analyses.notes: Lapis blue (lacivert) colored leaf confirmed. The strong blue-grey tone is consistent with the catalogue description 'bazı yapraklar lacivert'. The marbled paper visible on the right is a binding feature (ebrulu binding papers at the opening) and is not counted as page decoration.

decoration_observed: Left page: dark blue / grey-blue colored paper (lacivert) — second lacivert leaf confirmed
Right page: distinctly yellow / orange-tinted colored paper (sarı) — yellow leaf confirmed
Multi-colored scattered leaf programme confirmed: at minimum two distinct color registers (lacivert and sarı) visible across the spread
folio_analyses.notes: Yellow (sarı) colored leaf confirmed on right page of spread p015, alongside a further lacivert leaf on the left. This confirms the catalogue's multi-color description ('lacivert, yeşil, sarı ve mavi') and establishes that the colored leaves are not confined to the opening but are distributed through the body of the manuscript.

suggested_collections.reason: Further mecmûʿa volumes in the Manisa collection likely share paper stock and scribal practice; comparison of shelfmarks 4408/2 onward recommended. Manisa 4620/1 and 4633 also confirmed colored-paper (sarı boyalı) manuscripts.
Diyarbakır 649 and 12 (both Batch 3 confirmed colored-paper manuscripts) provide regional comparanda for multi-colored leaf programmes in provincial Ottoman Anatolian collections.
Significant holdings of Persian and Ottoman manuscripts with colored paper leaves; comparative material for establishing the geographic and chronological range of multi-colored leaf programmes.

provenance.notes: Catalogued by Rabia Şeckin. Held at Manisa İl Halk Kütüphanesi as risale 1 of mecmûʿa 4408. Earlier provenance unknown. Manisa (ancient Magnesia ad Sipylum) was an important Ottoman provincial capital and seat of the şehzade governorship; the local manuscript collection reflects both court-connected and local religious patronage.

analysis_metadata.image_quality_notes: IIIF viewer resolution sufficient for macro-level color identification (lacivert blue and sarı yellow clearly distinguishable). Chain-line watermarks not resolvable at viewer resolution. Pigment analysis not possible from digital images.
analysis_metadata.folios_not_examined: Majority of folios not systematically examined. Green (yeşil) leaves noted in catalogue not verified. Full extent and distribution of colored leaves across the manuscript unconfirmed. Beginning of text is missing (eserin başı eksiktir).
